page.title: 04BUILDINGS
page.content: St. Mary's church, Cratfield is the most impressive building. Built in flint in the Decorated and Perpendicular styles, it has a fine chancel roof. South of it is the Town House, once the Guildhall of St. Edmund, then Almshouses and now a weekend house.Houses range from 16th century to the present day. Several timber framed houses were brick faced during the 19th century. Old cottages are often changed into something rich and strange by their new owners. Farm buildings are generally large, modern and utilitarian, built chiefly of corrugated metal and breeze blocks. of three old wooden barns, one is now a sculptor's studio, one a minature theatre and the largest has been used for harvest suppers, a barn dance and once a production of Romeo and Juliet.
